required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Longitudinal Follow Up of Subjects Enrolled in Randomized Trial of Prenatal and Infancy Home Visitation
clinical_study.official_title: Longitudinal Follow Up of Subjects Enrolled in Randomized Trials of Prenatal and Infancy Home Visitation

brief_summary.textblock: The Elmira follow-up study is designed to assess the extent to which prenatal and infancy home visitation by nurses affects the life-course development of 19-year-old youth whose mothers received those services during pregnancy and the first two years of the child's life.

primary_outcome.measure: rates of pregnancy and out-of-wedlock child birth
educational achievement, including graduation from high school and participation in various types of post-high school education
participation in the work force, including enrollment in the armed services
use of substances (cigarettes, alcohol, and illegal drugs)
involvement with the criminal justice system (arrests, convictions, incarcerations, etc.)

arm_group.description: Nurse home visitation through child age 2.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant women prior to the 25th week of gestation
- no previous live births
- one of the following sociodemographic risk characteristics:
- young age (< 19 years at registration);
- unmarried
- low socioeconomic status (Medicaid status or no private insurance)

reference.citation: Izzo CV, Eckenrode JJ, Smith EG, Henderson CR, Cole R, Kitzman H, Olds DL. Reducing the impact of uncontrollable stressful life events through a program of nurse home visitation for new parents. Prev Sci. 2005 Dec;6(4):269-74.
